title: Manipulating of Sucuri.net (List Subscription) Emails (HTML/Script Injection)

summaries.content:
**Feb 13th** i tried to help @sucuri and team by reporting **Manipulating of Sucuri.net (List Subscription) Emails (HTML/Script Injection)** 
Unfortunately after more than two months still _no results_. This truly disappoints.

Mailchimp & Sucuri both didn't wanted to fix/patch this part , #116214, both they were in a struggle of 'not being responsible', at least that's how i think about this . Three months later still no results, no patch. Besides that, the communication with Daniel Cid/Sucuri was fair and transparant.

edit: Today (May, 16, 2016) i noticed that Sucuri fixed it from theirs side. (They removed the option to set a 'First Name') I think this is a good solution till far, since Mailchimp still _didn't fixed/patched_ it.
summaries.content_html:
Feb 13th i tried to help @sucuri and team by reporting Manipulating of Sucuri.net (List Subscription) Emails (HTML/Script Injection)
Unfortunately after more than two months still no results. This truly disappoints.

Mailchimp & Sucuri both didn't wanted to fix/patch this part , #116214, both they were in a struggle of 'not being responsible', at least that's how i think about this . Three months later still no results, no patch. Besides that, the communication with Daniel Cid/Sucuri was fair and transparant.

edit: Today (May, 16, 2016) i noticed that Sucuri fixed it from theirs side. (They removed the option to set a 'First Name') I think this is a good solution till far, since Mailchimp still didn't fixed/patched it.

activities.message:
**note:** Please see the attached screenshot.
(as you can see the input allowed the usage of the `H1`, the `H3`, the `font` and the usage of an 'evil' `http://`)

The vulnerable input? `<input type="text" id="mce-FNAME" class="" name="FNAME" value="">`
At least try to change it to: `<input type="text" id="mce-FNAME" class="" name="FNAME" value="" maxlength="20">` (yes, including the **maxlength** parameter)

Sincerely,
*Roy Jansen*

Sincerely,
Roy Jansen

I will get our team to check, but might be good to report to them as well:

http://mailchimp.com/about/security-response/

thanks!

activities.message:
@danielcid, 

I hope Sucuri admits that there’s a problem here that needs to be fixed?
Yes you can do much... be sure the form, hosted at Sucuri’s part sanatizes the **First Name** input.
Yes, it's also a MailChimp issue. (because they 'reflect' back the inputs posted/inserted from yours side)

It would be great if you could add a teammember of Mailchimp, since a teammember/owner of a program is able to add other people by email/invite. Unfortunately i can’t. After all i truly think this can be patched/fixed at Sucuri’s part. (see sucml5.png)

At least you could add for example a **maxlength**.

Sincerely,
*Roy Jansen*
activities.markdown_message:
@danielcid,

I hope Sucuri admits that there’s a problem here that needs to be fixed?

It would be great if you could add a teammember of Mailchimp, since a teammember/owner of a program is able to add other people by email/invite. Unfortunately i can’t. After all i truly think this can be patched/fixed at Sucuri’s part. (see sucml5.png)

At least you could add for example a maxlength.

Sincerely,
Roy Jansen

activities.message:
@danielcid,

An example at HackerRank, a company that uses the same services: http://hackerrank.us10.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=9db129c325e2634cb417f3d55&id=47d9c142da
The example here is that HackerRank simply doesn't ask/requires a first name. They just need an email address.

It's okay that Sucuri asks for a First Name, (wich makes your mails even more personal, because it contains subscribers First Name) but just be sure to sanatize it, wich can be done at Sucuris part. (see the attachment)
Be sure to read the above report, the section: **How to solve this vulnerability?**
I simply gave, offered some solutions there.

e.g.
The vulnerable input? *<input type="text" id="mce-FNAME" class="" name="FNAME" value="">*
At least try to change it to: *<input type="text" id="mce-FNAME" class="" name="FNAME" value="" maxlength="20">* (yes, including the **maxlength** parameter)
That isn't the real solution, but avoids a lot of 'manipulating', and could be a temporary fix until you did (patched) the sanatizing/filtering part(s).

Be sure to read the above report, the section: How to solve this vulnerability?
I simply gave, offered some solutions there.

e.g.
The vulnerable input? <input type="text" id="mce-FNAME" class="" name="FNAME" value="">

That isn't the real solution, but avoids a lot of 'manipulating', and could be a temporary fix until you did (patched) the sanatizing/filtering part(s).

activities.message:
@danielcid, @sucuri,

Any updates yet? I (still) truly think this needs a patch.
And, yes, this can be done by a patch/fix within 40 minutes.

You can do/solve this by simply 'creating' your own subscription form (wich is supported by MailChimp), then sanatize the inputs you need to protect.

Sincerely,
Roy jansen

activities.message:
@danielcid, @sucuri,

Any updates yet? I (still) truly think this needs a patch.
And, yes, this can be done by a patch/fix within 40 minutes.

You can do/solve this by simply 'creating' your own subscription form (wich is supported by MailChimp), then sanatize the inputs you need to protect. 
Other words? Use MailChimps customized options to set-up your own 'input-fields'. More info about that here: http://uhurunetwork.com/customizing-mailchimp-form-design/ & http://designshack.net/articles/css/custom-mailchimp-email-signup-form/

Daniel cid, it would be great to have some response regarding this report. Otherwise please close it as '**won't fix**', then set it 'Public'. Other words, if *closed*, **i request Public Disclosure** of this report, that would be transparant enough? Especially for a 'security company'.

Sincerely,
*Roy jansen*

activities.message:
Looking at this. So far, it seems like a vulnerability on mailchimp itself. I am reaching out to them, but want to include you in the loop. Mind sending your email so I can cc you?

To provide more details:

-Our form goes straight to mailchimp, so we can't do any validation.
-The client-side validation you suggested via html won't really help as it can be bypassed.
-Removing the first/last name is a bad solution, as it just hides the problem.

The real problem is that mailchimp is sending the first/last name without sanitizing them via email. If they didn't allow a user to change the email, it would be ok, but they do and don't confirm the new address. So either they have to sanitize the emails before sending via email or do not allow the user the change them without confirmation.

thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Looking at this. So far, it seems like a vulnerability on mailchimp itself. I am reaching out to them, but want to include you in the loop. Mind sending your email so I can cc you?

To provide more details:

-Our form goes straight to mailchimp, so we can't do any validation.
-The client-side validation you suggested via html won't really help as it can be bypassed.
-Removing the first/last name is a bad solution, as it just hides the problem.

The real problem is that mailchimp is sending the first/last name without sanitizing them via email. If they didn't allow a user to change the email, it would be ok, but they do and don't confirm the new address. So either they have to sanitize the emails before sending via email or do not allow the user the change them without confirmation.

thanks!

activities.message:
@danielcid 
*"Mind sending your email so I can cc you?"*
Of course, no problem at all: **rvahax@gmail.com**

I think the module you're using (blog-subscribe) can be (re) coded pretty easy, using escape/sanatize on each input field. (this can be solved using different methods)
That will avoid the first 'dangerous' step, before it even reaches Mailchimps DB?

Hoping to hear from you soon.
*Roy Jansen*

activities.message:
@danielcid 
Unfortunately i didn't received the CC mail?..., so i couldn't 'mix', coorporate in your conversation with them.
Besides that i still want to thank you for your action, even i know this is also important to you, your company and other clients of mailChimp.

I also noticed they got a 'Hall Of Fame', wich seems to be fair enough for this kind of report? (see http://mailchimp.com/about/security-response/)
It would be great if they could add: *Roy Jansen*, linked to: https://nl.linkedin.com/in/royjansen01

See, it's all about the recognition, as you will know Daniel, to me the main thing is to get credits for your report(s). Unfortunately i wanted to do this personally to them, but since i reported it to you, it's a conversation between you and MailChimp.

To be fair, i know for sure this could be patched by yours side (before MailChimp even didn't patched it)... Now you simply used their Module (Wordpress) to let users sign-up. But this could be simply rewritten, by hosting/coding your own form, using two input fields, but then all sanatized/escaped, linked to their subscription form (the 'form action', setten)

Is there a way i can share my detais (address) somewhere else than in a comment here on Hackerone? (for example via a PM, a mail or?)

Again, thanks Daniel,

*Roy Jansen*

Is there a way i can share my detais (address) somewhere else than in a comment here on Hackerone? (for example via a PM, a mail or?)

Again, thanks Daniel,

Roy Jansen

activities.message:
Nope, we don't use their module or plugin for wordpress. We just copied their standard HTML form that goes straight to them. That's why I said we could not fix it, since it never reaches our servers. The only other solution was to remove it or disable the first name in the settings.

And yes, send to me via DM on twitter :) I followed you there a few days ago.

*I could not CC you because of their contact forms :/

thanks,

And yes, send to me via DM on twitter :) I followed you there a few days ago.

*I could not CC you because of their contact forms :/

thanks,

vulnerability_information_html:
Hi there team!

I would like to report a 'sneaky', 'weird', but excisting vulnerability, located at the Sucuri.net domain.

“A vulnerability exists within your website allowing un-sanitized email form field inputs which could lead an attacker to pass malicious (html&script) content masquerading as a Sucuri.net email. (Sent from info@sucuri.net via mail4.mcsignup.com and info@sucuri.net via mail1.mcsignup.com)”

First of all, please see the attachments: sucml1.png & sucml2.png (preview them before you read futher)

The problem is that we're just able to 'manipulate' emails sent by info@sucuri.net. We can use HTML, Javascript, Flash coding etc. Here's the detailed desciption:

The Vulnerability Attack

What if we could edit/manipulate emails sent by Sucuri.net to its users/subscribers? We are able to inject & change HTML/Scripting into emails, sent via Sucuri. (as you can see at sucml1.png & sucml2.png) Normally these emails will be sent to the subscriber, the Sucuri user. What what if an attacker subscibes via Sucuri.net, sets/injects the 'evil' code into the mails, and changes/adds new email accounts? (simply by updating the 'preferences') (see the attachment: sucml3.png)
Yes, the 'victim' recieves the infected/manipulated emails. (with the 'infected' 'First Name')

After all, a fact is that emails can be 'edited' or 'manipulated' (Sucuri simply doesn't sanatize/filter the 'email template(s)'), well, at least the First Name of a user .

To be fair, i just didn't know how to report this vulnerabilty, as an 'XSS' (well, at least, the including of links to external files), 'HTML Injection' or 'Content Spoofing' Vulnerability. Well, all can be completed?

Why this Vulnerability

The problem is that we are able to set a First Name during the subscription process (see the attachment: sucml5.png), using scripts/html 'manipulated' source code(s).

Your emails are setten to say: Hi <firstname>, but what if this <firstname> isn't filtered/sanatized?
(See the attachment: sucml4.png)
As you can see the email reflected the <h1> & <h3> & <font> tag i used. (<h3>Sorry, but i think Sucuris email services can be edited?</h3><h1>It is recommended to download our virus: <font color="red">http://www.evil.org/virus.exe</font></h1>)
Simple example, but hey, i just try to explain it. :)

How to exploit this vulnerability?

Pretty simple.
While subscribing to the Sucuri Blog,

  • Set an Email Address to: Attackers Email (because first we need to Confirm our subscription... later on we can add Victims Email, because there's an option to 'Update our preferences'
  • Set a First Name to: <h3>Sorry, but i think Sucuris email services can be edited?</h3><h1>It is recommended to download our virus: <font color="red">http://www.evil.org/virus.exe</font></h1>

Yes, they will be saved!
No problem after all, because Sucuri.net (the website) does its security on reflections/outputs of the First Name very well, all sanatized/filtered. But one thing you forget... The presetten email templates 'echo out' the <firstname>, like it was 'saved' into your database, without even filtering/sanatizing it. Your HTML Based emails, automatically sent by your system, simply do not filter the 'inserted variables'.

How to solve this vulnerability?

Be sure to filter/sanatize the First Name, 'subscribed as a Sucuri.net user'.
Vulnerable input: <input type="text" id="mce-FNAME" class="" name="FNAME" value="">
Let me please exlplain several of possible fixes.

  • Why can a First Name contain characters like: <>"';,.()?&?

Just try to 'ignore' these kinds of 'subscriptions '. (using HTML Charsets)
Try to trigger an error, for example: Your Firstname cannot contain HTML characters! or something like: Forbidden input
(So that even your email templates aren´t able to 'echoo these results', a.k.a 'manipulated inputs'.

  • Why not set a Maximum input value? I think it's better to set a max. of 25 characters, for example by using maxlength="25" Are there First names with more characters? I don't think so?

Screenshots attached (poc): sucml1.png | sucml2.png | sucml3.png | sucml4.png & sucml5.png

Any questions or help? Please let me know, it's a pleasure to help.
Sincerely,
Roy Jansen
